verses.sanskrit: sakheti matvā prasabham yad uktaṃ he kṛṣṇa he yādava he sakheti | ajānatā mahimānam tavedam mayā pramādāt praṇayena vāpi ||
verses.transliteration: sakhā iti matvā prasabham yat uktam — he kṛṣṇa he yādava he sakhā iti | ajānatā mahimānam tava idam mayā pramādāt praṇayena vā api ||
verses.translation: Whatever I have spoken carelessly — 'O Krishna, O Yadava, O friend' — addressing You as a companion, not knowing this greatness of Yours, out of negligence or out of love...

word_breakdown.meaning: thinking (You) as a friend / companion
presumptuously, boldly, without restraint
whatever was said / spoken
O Krishna! — familiar address
O Yadava! — addressing by clan name
O friend! — intimate form of address
not knowing, out of ignorance
Your greatness / glory / majesty
this (greatness)
by me
out of carelessness, negligence, heedlessness
out of love, affection, intimacy
or even, or perhaps

commentary.dadaji: Beloved child, see how Arjuna's heart breaks open in this moment. He had called Krishna 'friend' his whole life — and now, trembling before the Infinite, he realizes that his most intimate companion was the Lord of all creation. This is not mere regret; it is the sweetest kind of awakening. The very audacity of calling God your friend, born of love, is not a sin — it is perhaps the highest privilege. And yet, once the veil lifts, the heart can only bow in wonder and ask forgiveness for the smallness of its previous sight.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse is a profound teaching about the relationship between jñāna and bhakti. Arjuna had been living with Brahman Itself — the very Consciousness described in the Māṇḍūkya Upaniṣad as 'prajñānam brahma' — treating It as a charioteer and friend. The word 'ajānatā' points to avidyā, the fundamental not-knowing that veils the Absolute. And yet the Upaniṣads also say 'tat tvam asi' — even in the intimate address 'sakhā,' there is a deeper truth being lived, unknowingly. Arjuna's pramāda was never truly a fault; it was the form ignorance takes when it is about to dissolve into knowledge.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda taught that the Lord wears countless masks for His devotees — friend, parent, beloved — and that each relationship is a path leading back to the One. Arjuna's cry 'O friend!' was never wrong; it was the devotion of the heart finding its natural expression. But now the cosmic vision has burned away the personal mask, and what remains is the Infinite Light. This transition — from the personal to the Impersonal and back — is the very movement of spiritual evolution. Arjuna's apology is really the soul's first conscious recognition of the Divine in all its boundlessness.
commentary.goyandka: In this verse and the next, Arjuna seeks forgiveness for speaking to the Lord with the presumptuous familiarity of a friend, without recognizing His supreme divine nature. The words 'pramādāt' (through carelessness) and 'praṇayena' (through affection) indicate two different possible causes — either forgetfulness or the intimacy of love. Śrī Śaṅkarācārya notes that praṇaya-janya addressing, born of deep love, is less blameworthy than that born of mere negligence. Arjuna's confession here demonstrates the profound humility that follows genuine darśana of the Divine.

verses.sanskrit: yac cāvahāsārtham asatkṛto'si vihāra-śayyāsana-bhojaneshu | eko'thavāpy acyuta tat-samakṣam tat kṣāmaye tvām aham aprameyam ||
verses.transliteration: yat ca avahāsa-artham asat-kṛtaḥ asi vihāra-śayyā-āsana-bhojaneshu | ekaḥ atha vā api acyuta tat-samakṣam tat kṣāmaye tvām aham aprameyam ||
verses.translation: And however I disrespected You in jest — during games, on a bed, seated, or at meals — alone or in others' presence, O Acyuta — I ask Your forgiveness, O Immeasurable One.

word_breakdown.meaning: and whatever

on a bed / while resting
while seated
during meals / eating
alone, in private
or even, or perhaps (in public)
in the presence of others, before witnesses
O Acyuta — the Unfailing, Immovable One (epithet of Krishna)
I beg Your forgiveness, I beseech You
O Immeasurable One, O Incomprehensible One

commentary.dadaji: How intimate was the friendship of Arjuna and Krishna! They had eaten together, slept under the same roof, laughed and joked in the easy familiarity of the dearest friends. Now Arjuna's soul aches — not because those moments were wrong, but because he sees the infinite grace that permitted them. The Lord allowed Himself to be teased, joked with, even momentarily forgotten as God — just so that love could flow naturally and freely. The name 'Acyuta,' the Unfailing One, is perfectly placed here: despite all of Arjuna's casual disregard, the Lord never withdrew His grace, never faltered, never fell away. That is the meaning of Acyuta.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The word 'aprameyam' — Immeasurable — is the key to this verse. Arjuna is saying: I treated the Immeasurable as measurable, the Infinite as finite, the Universal as personal. This is precisely what māyā does — it presents the boundless Ātman within the bounded form. The Kena Upaniṣad says 'yat manasā na manute' — That which cannot be grasped by mind. Yet the mind of Arjuna, through the intimacy of love, had grasped only the surface of the form. The Vivekacūḍāmaṇi would say this is not a fault but the very limitation of the human condition before the arising of tattva-viveka, discriminative wisdom.
commentary.yogananda: The great ones who live with an Avatar often fail to recognize the full stature of the soul before them — this is the Lord's own cosmic play, His līlā. Yogananda wrote of how the disciples of Jesus similarly joked and ate and walked with the Christ without fully realizing the cosmic Christ behind the gentle Galilean. In the same way, Arjuna's casual familiarity was part of the divine arrangement — the Lord took human form precisely so that love could flow without the inhibition of awe. Now that the cosmic form has been revealed, Arjuna's heart is enlarged to hold both the personal and the universal simultaneously.
commentary.goyandka: This verse lists specific circumstances — sport, rest, sitting, and eating — to indicate that Arjuna's casual behavior spanned all aspects of daily life in Krishna's company. The dual mention of 'ekaḥ' (alone) and 'tat-samakṣam' (in the presence of others) covers both private and public instances of irreverence. The epithet 'acyuta' here is particularly significant, as it points to the Lord's unshakeable nature — He who never falls, never changes — underscoring how misplaced was Arjuna's casual treatment. 'Aprameyam' (Immeasurable) at the verse's end reinforces the gulf between what Arjuna had previously perceived and what the Viśvarūpa has now revealed.

verses.sanskrit: pitāsi lokasya carācarasya tvam asya pūjyaś ca gurur garīyān | na tvat-samo'sty abhyadhikaḥ kuto'nyo loka-traye'py apratima-prabhāva ||
verses.transliteration: pitā asi lokasya cara-acarasya tvam asya pūjyaḥ ca guruḥ garīyān | na tvat-samaḥ asti abhyadhikaḥ kutaḥ anyaḥ loka-traye api apratima-prabhāva ||
verses.translation: You are the Father of the world, of all moving and unmoving beings; You are its most venerable Teacher, greater than the greatest. There is none equal to You — how then could there be another greater? Your glory is unmatched in the three worlds, O Being of Incomparable Power.

word_breakdown.meaning: You are the Father
of the world
of the moving and the unmoving / animate and inanimate
You of this (world)
most worthy of worship, most venerable
the Teacher, the Preceptor
greater, weightier, more exalted (than all gurus)
equal to You
one who surpasses, greater than
how can there be another? — rhetorical
even in the three worlds (heaven, earth, netherworld)
O One of Incomparable Power / Glory — vocative epithet

commentary.dadaji: After the trembling apology, Arjuna's heart overflows into praise — and what praise! He calls Krishna the Father of all that moves and all that stands still, the Guru who is greater than any teacher the universe has known. Dear child, this is the natural movement of a soul after genuine repentance: it does not wallow in guilt but rises immediately into adoration. The word 'garīyān' — weightier, greater — suggests a guru so vast that no scale can measure Him. And 'apratima-prabhāva' — glory without equal — is not a mere compliment; it is the soul's recognition that it has been in the presence of the Absolute all along.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse encapsulates the Vedantic understanding of the Paramātman as the universal Ground. The Taittirīya Upaniṣad declares 'so'kāmayata — bahu syām' — He desired to be many, and became all moving and unmoving things. Arjuna's recognition of Krishna as 'pitā lokasya carācarasya' directly echoes this Upaniṣadic understanding that the Supreme is the source and sustainer of all existence. The statement 'na tvat-samaḥ asti' — none is equal to You — aligns with the Śvetāśvatara Upaniṣad's 'na tasya samāḥ' (there is no equal of His). Arjuna has moved from devotional awe to genuine philosophical recognition.
commentary.yogananda: The recognition of the Divine as the ultimate Father and Teacher is central to Yogananda's teachings on the Guru principle. He taught that behind every true guru stands the one Guru — the Divine Consciousness itself — and here Arjuna recognizes that Krishna is that primordial Guru from whom all teaching originates. 'Gurur garīyān' — the Teacher who is greater than the greatest — points to the Sat-Guru, the Eternal Teacher who does not merely transmit knowledge but is Knowledge itself. When the soul truly sees this, as Arjuna does here, the relationship with the outer guru deepens into union with the inner Infinite.
commentary.goyandka: Having sought forgiveness, Arjuna now articulates the reason for that forgiveness: Krishna is not merely a friend but the very Father and supreme Guru of all creation. The inclusion of both 'cara' (moving) and 'acara' (unmoving) is the Gita's comprehensive way of indicating all existence without exception. The rhetorical question 'abhyadhikaḥ kutaḥ anyaḥ' — 'how then could there be another superior?' — is a powerful logical argument: if none is even equal, the question of superiority becomes meaningless. The epithet 'apratima-prabhāva' confirms that Krishna's glory is literally without comparison in all the three realms of existence.

verses.sanskrit: tasmāt praṇamya praṇidhāya kāyam prasādaye tvām aham īśam īḍyam | piteva putrasya sakheva sakhyuḥ priyaḥ priyāyārhasi deva soḍhum ||
verses.transliteration: tasmāt praṇamya praṇidhāya kāyam prasādaye tvām aham īśam īḍyam | pitā iva putrasya sakhā iva sakhyuḥ priyaḥ priyāyāḥ arhasi deva soḍhum ||
verses.translation: Therefore, prostrating my body in salutation, I beseech You, O adorable Lord — as a father forgives a son, a friend a dear friend, a beloved a lover — please bear with me, O God.

word_breakdown.meaning: therefore, for this reason
having bowed down, prostrating in salutation
laying the body down fully, prostrating the whole body
I propitiate You, I beseech Your grace
the Lord, the Master of all
the adorable One, worthy of praise and worship
as a father (bears with) a son
as a friend (forgives) a friend
as a beloved (bears with) a lover
You should, You are worthy, please (do)
O God, O Resplendent One
to bear, to forgive, to put up with, to endure

commentary.dadaji: This verse is one of the most tender moments in the entire Gita. Arjuna does not stand before Krishna with the stiff formality of a devotee approaching a deity — he appeals to the three most intimate relationships human beings know: parent and child, friend and friend, lover and beloved. In doing so, he is acknowledging that his connection with Krishna contains all of these. How beautiful is this theology, dear child — the Lord is not a distant judge but the closest Father, the truest Friend, the most beloved of beloveds. And we may come to Him precisely as such, asking Him to bear our smallness with the tenderness only the Infinite can muster.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The three analogies — father-son, friend-friend, beloved-lover — represent the three primary modes of intimate relationship recognized in Indian thought, and Arjuna invokes all three. This is significant from a Vedantic standpoint: Arjuna is recognizing that in every relationship, the Absolute is present as the ground of intimacy itself. The Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad declares that we do not love the husband for the husband's sake, but for the sake of the Ātman within. Here, every loving relationship Arjuna has known with Krishna was, at its core, the Self loving the Self. The prostration of the body — 'praṇidhāya kāyam' — represents the ego surrendering to this recognition.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda beautifully taught that God plays the role of every relationship in our lives — and that the love we feel for parents, friends, and beloved is but a limited reflection of the infinite love of the Divine. Arjuna intuitively grasps this truth when he asks Krishna to forgive him 'as a father, as a friend, as a beloved.' He is not using mere poetic metaphors; he is accurately describing the many faces through which the Infinite had been pouring love into his life. The full prostration — 'praṇidhāya kāyam' — is the outer sign of the inner surrender: the small self laying itself completely at the feet of the All-Self.
commentary.goyandka: This verse demonstrates Arjuna's profound humility after the vision of the Viśvarūpa. The act of 'praṇidhāya kāyam' — laying the entire body on the ground in full prostration — is the bodily expression of total surrender. Śrīdhara Svāmī notes that Arjuna appeals to three categories of close relationship — father-son, friend-friend, and lover-beloved — because each represents a different quality of forbearance: the father's unconditional patience, the friend's informal forgiveness, and the beloved's tender tolerance. By invoking all three, Arjuna covers every possible mode of gracious pardon. The verse ends with the beautiful dual epithets 'īśa' (the all-powerful Lord) and 'īḍya' (the eternally adorable), reminding us of the complete paradox of the Lord's nature.

verses.sanskrit: adṛṣṭa-pūrvaṃ hṛṣito'smi dṛṣṭvā bhayena ca pravyathitaṃ mano me | tad eva me darśaya deva rūpaṃ prasīda deveśa jagan-nivāsa ||
verses.transliteration: adṛṣṭa-pūrvam hṛṣitaḥ asmi dṛṣṭvā bhayena ca pravyathitam manaḥ me | tat eva me darśaya deva rūpam prasīda deva-īśa jagan-nivāsa ||
verses.translation: I am gladdened having seen what was never seen before, and yet my mind is shaken with terror. Show me that very form, O God; be gracious, O Lord of Gods, O Abode of the Universe.

word_breakdown.meaning: that which has never been seen before, unprecedented
I am thrilled, delighted, overjoyed
having seen
with fear, with terror
deeply agitated, shaken, trembling
my mind
that very (form), that same (four-armed form)
show (me), reveal
O God, O Resplendent One
the form, the gentle personal form
be gracious, be pleased, show mercy
O Lord of Gods, O God of gods
O Abode of the Universe, O Dwelling-place of all worlds

commentary.dadaji: This is the honest cry of every soul that has glimpsed the Infinite — joy and terror together, inseparable. The Cosmic Vision is too vast for the human vessel, and Arjuna speaks for all of us when he says: I am thrilled, yes — but I am also trembling. Dear one, do not be afraid of this trembling. It is not weakness; it is the appropriate response of the finite meeting the Infinite. And now, having seen the All, Arjuna asks to see the Face — the personal, gentle, four-armed form of his Lord. This is not a step backward; it is the recognition that the Personal and the Universal are one, and that we need the Personal to be able to approach the Universal at all.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Arjuna's dual experience — joy ('hṛṣitaḥ asmi') and terror ('pravyathitam manaḥ') — is what Rudolf Otto in 'The Idea of the Holy' describes as the experience of the 'mysterium tremendum et fascinans': the Mystery that is simultaneously terrifying and fascinating. In the Kaṭha Upaniṣad, the Ātman is described as 'mahad bhayam vajram udyatam' — the great fear, like a raised thunderbolt. The Absolute, when directly perceived, shatters the limited ego-consciousness. Arjuna's request to see the gentle four-armed form again is not a retreat from non-dual vision but the recognition that even the highest realization must be integrated through the personal relationship between jīva and Īśvara.
commentary.yogananda: The simultaneous experience of bliss and fear that Arjuna describes is what the mystics call the 'numinous experience' — the direct contact with the Divine Reality that both enraptures and overwhelms the soul. Yogananda wrote that the first time a devotee truly feels the presence of God, the ego is so shattered by the encounter that it trembles. This is not the fear of punishment but the natural response of the drop realizing it is about to dissolve into the Ocean. Arjuna's prayer — 'prasīda deveśa jagan-nivāsa' — is the turning of the stricken soul toward the personal Face of the Divine, which alone can make the Infinite approachable.
commentary.goyandka: This verse captures the paradox of the devotee's heart in the presence of divine epiphany: simultaneous delight and dread. The word 'adṛṣṭa-pūrvam' confirms that this vision was truly unprecedented — no human had ever seen what Arjuna witnessed. The three epithets at the verse's close — 'deva' (God), 'deveśa' (Lord of Gods), and 'jagan-nivāsa' (Abode of the Universe) — represent a conscious escalation, acknowledging the full divine status of the One before whom Arjuna now trembles. The phrase 'tat eva me darśaya rūpam' — 'show me that very form' — is a specific request for the four-armed Viṣṇu form that appeared before the cosmic vision was revealed.

verses.sanskrit: kirīṭinaṃ gadinaṃ cakra-hastam icchāmi tvāṃ draṣṭum ahaṃ tathaiva | tenaiva rūpeṇa catur-bhujena sahasra-bāho bhava viśva-mūrte ||
verses.transliteration: kirīṭinam gadinam cakra-hastam icchāmi tvām draṣṭum aham tathā eva | tena eva rūpeṇa catuḥ-bhujena sahasra-bāho bhava viśva-mūrte ||
verses.translation: I wish to see You wearing the crown, holding the mace and discus, just as You were before. Assume that four-armed form again, O Thousand-Armed One, O Universal Form.

word_breakdown.meaning: wearing the crown / diadem
holding the mace (gadā)
with the discus (cakra) in hand
I wish, I desire
to see You
I, just as before / in the same manner
with that very same form
four-armed, with four arms
O Thousand-Armed One — vocative (from the cosmic form)
become, assume, be
O Universal Form, O One whose body is the cosmos — vocative

commentary.dadaji: How exquisite is this moment — Arjuna, still addressing Krishna as the Thousand-Armed Universal Form, asking to see the four-armed form of Viṣṇu. He has not forgotten what he has seen; he carries the Infinite even as he reaches for the Personal. The crown, the mace, the discus — these are not limitations but love-marks, the signs by which the devotee's heart recognizes its Lord. Dear child, we too need our own 'four-armed form' — the particular face of God that the heart knows and loves — even while our minds bow before the boundless. This is not spiritual regression; it is the wisdom to hold the vast in the vessel of the intimate.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The apparent contradiction in this verse — Arjuna addressing Krishna as 'sahasra-bāho' (Thousand-Armed) and 'viśva-mūrte' (Universal Form) even while requesting the four-armed personal form — reveals a profound non-dual understanding. Arjuna is not confused; he is recognizing that the personal and the universal are aspects of the same Reality. The Māṇḍūkya Upaniṣad distinguishes between 'saguṇa' and 'nirguṇa' Brahman, but ultimately declares them non-different. Arjuna has been catapulted into a momentary experience of the nirguṇa and now wisely asks to return to the saguṇa form that enables ongoing loving relationship — for saguṇa bhakti is the bridge through which most souls travel toward the Absolute.
commentary.yogananda: In this poignant request, Arjuna demonstrates the highest spiritual intelligence: he has seen the Infinite but asks for the Beloved's personal form. Yogananda often said that the impersonal Absolute and the personal God are two aspects of the one Reality, and that the devotee needs the personal aspect to maintain the flow of love. The specific details Arjuna asks for — the crown, the mace, the discus, the four arms — are not merely aesthetic preferences but the sacred iconography by which the heart recognizes its Beloved. Even as we must one day merge into the Infinite Ocean, the journey there is made joyful by the Personal Form that walks beside us.
commentary.goyandka: This verse reveals that Arjuna had previously beheld the four-armed Viṣṇu form (catuḥ-bhuja-rūpa) of the Lord, which was then expanded into the thousand-armed cosmic manifestation (viśvarūpa). He now requests a return to that intermediate personal-divine form, which, while transcendent, is more accessible than the terrifying cosmic vision. The commentator Madhusūdana Sarasvatī notes the beautiful irony: Arjuna calls Krishna 'sahasra-bāho' (Thousand-Armed) even while asking Him to show the four-armed form, indicating that for Arjuna, both forms are now simultaneously real. The four divine attributes — crown (sovereignty), gadā (power), cakra (protective will), and four arms (completeness) — together represent the full divine personality of Nārāyaṇa.

verses.sanskrit: śrī-bhagavān uvāca — mayā prasannena tavārjunedam rūpaṃ paraṃ darśitam ātma-yogāt | tejo-mayaṃ viśvam anantam ādyam yan me tvad-anyena na dṛṣṭa-pūrvam ||
verses.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca — mayā prasannena tava arjuna idam rūpam param darśitam ātma-yogāt | tejaḥ-mayam viśvam anantam ādyam yat me tvat-anyena na dṛṣṭa-pūrvam ||
verses.translation: The Blessed Lord said: O Arjuna, pleased with you, I showed you this Supreme Form through My own yogic power — radiant, universal, infinite, primordial — which no one but you has ever seen before.

word_breakdown.meaning: the Blessed Lord said
by Me, who am pleased / by grace
for you, out of grace toward you
O Arjuna
this Supreme Form
shown, revealed
through My own yogic power, through the power of the Self
made of radiance / pure light, resplendent
universal, encompassing all worlds
infinite, endless, boundless
primordial, the Original, the First
by any other than you
never seen before, not seen previously

commentary.dadaji: The Lord begins with 'prasannena' — 'pleased with you.' After all the trembling and the terror and the apologies, the first word of God's response is grace and delight. Dear child, this is the nature of the Divine: it is not the cosmic vision that is the gift — it is the love behind it. 'Ātma-yogāt' — 'through My own power' — means that no merit, no ritual, no study could have earned this vision; it was pure grace, pure love. And the Lord quietly adds: 'no one but you has seen this.' What is the meaning of this privilege? It is not favoritism; it is the fruit of a lifetime of friendship with the Divine.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The phrase 'ātma-yogāt' is philosophically critical. It means 'through the power of My own Ātman' — indicating that the Viśvarūpa was not an external show but a revelation of what Krishna's innermost Self actually is. The Kaṭha Upaniṣad says 'nāyam ātmā pravacanena labhyaḥ' — the Ātman is not attained by lectures or study. Here the Lord confirms this: no external means can produce this vision; it arises only from the Lord's own grace, His 'prasāda.' The four qualifiers — tejomayam (radiant), viśvam (universal), anantam (infinite), ādyam (primordial) — correspond beautifully to the four pādas of the Māṇḍūkya Upaniṣad's description of Brahman.
commentary.yogananda: The Lord's declaration that He revealed the cosmic form 'through My own yoga-power' is a profound teaching on divine grace. Yogananda taught that the highest spiritual experiences are never the product of personal effort alone — they are always gifts of divine grace responding to a pure and surrendered heart. 'Tejomayam' — made of pure light — describes the nature of cosmic consciousness as Yogananda experienced it in his great samādhi: not darkness or void but infinite, blinding light. This is the light described in the Gita as 'sahasra-sūrya-sam' — like the light of a thousand suns. Arjuna was privileged to see what yogis spend lifetimes seeking.
commentary.goyandka: The Lord's response establishes three important facts about the Viśvarūpa darśana. First, it was given out of divine 'prasāda' — grace and delight — not earned through any human effort. Second, it was revealed through 'ātma-yoga,' the Lord's own inconceivable divine power, which is different from any yoga practiced by human beings. Third, it was truly unprecedented — 'tvad-anyena na dṛṣṭa-pūrvam' — meaning that despite all the great sages and devotees who had come before, none had received this exact revelation. The four attributes of the form — tejomayam, viśvam, anantam, ādyam — establish it as the supreme Brahman-manifestation, beyond all partial or sectarian visions.

verses.sanskrit: na veda-yajñādhyayanair na dānair na ca kriyābhir na tapobhir ugraiḥ | evaṃ-rūpaḥ śakya ahaṃ nṛ-loke draṣṭuṃ tvad-anyena kuru-pravīra ||
verses.transliteration: na veda-yajña-adhyayanaiḥ na dānaiḥ na ca kriyābhiḥ na tapobhiḥ ugraiḥ | evam-rūpaḥ śakyaḥ aham nṛ-loke draṣṭum tvat-anyena kuru-pravīra ||
verses.translation: I cannot be seen in this form — as you have seen Me — through Vedic sacrifices, study, gifts, ritual acts, or severe austerities, by any other than you in the world of men, O Kuru Hero.

word_breakdown.meaning: not through Vedic sacrifices and scriptural study
not through charitable gifts / donations
not through ritual actions / ceremonies
not through fierce / severe austerities
in this form, as I appeared in this cosmic form
I am able to be / I can be (seen)
in the world of men, in the human realm
to be seen, to behold
by any other than you
O Hero of the Kurus, O best of the Kuru dynasty

commentary.dadaji: The Lord lists all the paths that human effort has devised — Vedas, sacrifice, study, giving, rituals, austerities — and gently declares that none of them, however noble, can compel this vision. This is not a dismissal of these practices; they purify the heart and make it ready. But the final opening of the door is always grace. Dear child, this is very reassuring: you do not have to earn God's highest gift. You have to love, you have to prepare, you have to sincerely seek — and then, in the Lord's own time and way, the vision comes. Arjuna received it not through grand ritual but through a lifetime of love and surrender.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse is a direct statement from the Absolute that self-effort, however thorough, cannot by itself produce the highest realization. The Kenopaniṣad is equally unambiguous: 'na tatra cakṣur gacchati' — the eye does not go there; 'na vāg gacchati' — speech does not reach there. All the religious and spiritual technologies listed — Vedic learning, sacrifice, charity, ritual, tapas — belong to the realm of sādhana, personal effort. But the vision of the Supreme belongs to the realm of anugraha, divine grace. The Praśna Upaniṣad says the Ātman reveals Itself 'tasmai eṣa ātmā vivṛṇute tanūṃ svām' — It reveals Itself to the one whom It chooses. Grace is not arbitrary; it follows love.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda often distinguished between 'self-effort' and 'grace,' teaching that while effort is necessary to purify the vessel, the divine wine that fills it is always a free gift. This verse provides the cosmic confirmation of that teaching. The list of external religious practices — Vedas, yajna, dāna, kriyā, tapas — represents the entire spectrum of human religious effort. The Lord says: none of these, by themselves, can produce this vision. This does not mean these practices are useless — they are essential disciplines. But they must be animated by love and surrendered to grace, or they remain mere technique without transformation.
commentary.goyandka: This verse repeats and strengthens the teaching of verse 47 regarding the inaccessibility of the Viśvarūpa through conventional religious means. The five listed pathways — Vedic sacrifice, scriptural study, charitable giving, ritual observance, and severe austerity — represent the complete catalogue of external religious practice. The word 'ugraiḥ' (fierce, severe) applied to 'tapas' indicates even the most intense self-mortification cannot compel this revelation. The epithet 'kuru-pravīra' — 'O Hero among the Kurus' — is significant: even the bravest warrior of the most illustrious lineage could not have obtained this through his own power; it was purely a gift of the Lord's pleasure.

verses.sanskrit: mā te vyathā mā ca vimūḍha-bhāvo dṛṣṭvā rūpaṃ ghoram īdṛṅ mamedam | vyapeta-bhīḥ prīta-manāḥ punas tvaṃ tad eva me rūpam idaṃ prapaśya ||
verses.transliteration: mā te vyathā mā ca vimūḍha-bhāvaḥ dṛṣṭvā rūpam ghoram īdṛk mama idam | vyapeta-bhīḥ prīta-manāḥ punaḥ tvam tat eva me rūpam idam prapaśya ||
verses.translation: Let there be no anguish for you, no bewilderment, having seen this terrifying form of Mine. With fear completely gone and with a glad heart, see again that very form of Mine — the gentle one.

word_breakdown.meaning: let there be no anguish / distress for you
and let there be no bewilderment / confusion
having seen
the terrifying form, the fearsome appearance
this of Mine, such as this (My form)
with fear completely gone / departed, fearless
with a glad heart, with a loving and joyful mind
again, you
that very (form), that same gentle form
My form
see this now clearly, behold this once more

commentary.dadaji: With boundless tenderness, the Lord tells Arjuna: 'Do not be afraid. Do not be confused.' After the terror of the cosmic vision, these words fall like rain on a parched earth. And then the Lord says: 'See again My form.' The gentleness of God is not a lesser truth than the terror of the Infinite — it is the Infinite choosing to be approachable out of love. Dear child, the God who can dissolve worlds is also the God who says to trembling Arjuna: 'Be glad again, dear friend. I am here. Look at Me.' This is the ultimate comfort — that behind all the cosmic vastness is an intimate tenderness that knows your name.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The transition in this verse — from 'ghora rūpa' (terrifying form) to the gentle personal form — mirrors the Upaniṣadic journey from 'neti, neti' (not this, not this) to 'tat tvam asi' (That thou art). The terrifying cosmic vision represents the nirguṇa, formless aspect of Brahman which the unprepared mind cannot sustain. The command 'vyapeta-bhīḥ prīta-manāḥ prapaśya' — 'with fear gone and gladness in the heart, see' — describes the mental state required for genuine spiritual vision: equanimity and joy, not effort and fear. The Chāndogya Upaniṣad says 'nāyam ātmā bala-hīnena labhyaḥ' — but the 'bala' (strength) needed is not physical but the inner strength of fearlessness and love.
commentary.yogananda: The compassion of the Lord in this verse is infinitely moving. Having shown Arjuna the full terror and glory of cosmic consciousness, He now draws the trembling devotee back to the personal relationship with the words 'prīta-manāḥ' — 'with a joyful heart.' Yogananda taught that true realization does not culminate in fear but in joy — 'ever-new joy' was his phrase for the nature of Ānanda, the bliss of Brahman. The cosmic vision may begin with terror but it must end in delight, because the nature of the Absolute is Sat-Cit-Ānanda: pure Being, pure Consciousness, pure Bliss. Krishna is now guiding Arjuna from the terror of the first encounter toward the bliss of integration.
commentary.goyandka: This verse represents the Lord's transition from the revelation of the Viśvarūpa back to His personal four-armed and then two-armed human forms. The phrase 'mā te vyathā' — 'let there be no anguish for you' — reflects the Lord's infinite compassion for the limited capacity of the human mind. The condition 'vyapeta-bhīḥ prīta-manāḥ' is instructive: the vision of the Lord's gentle form should be received not with residual fear from the cosmic revelation, but with a newly purified and joyful heart. 'Tat eva me rūpam' — 'that very form of Mine' — refers specifically to the four-armed Viṣṇu form that will now once more manifest before Arjuna.

verses.sanskrit: sañjaya uvāca — ity arjunaṃ vāsudevas tathoktā svakaṃ rūpaṃ darśayāmāsa bhūyaḥ | āśvāsayāmāsa ca bhītam enaṃ bhūtvā punaḥ saumya-vapur mahātmā ||
verses.transliteration: sañjayaḥ uvāca — iti arjunam vāsudevaḥ tathā uktvā svakam rūpam darśayāmāsa bhūyaḥ | āśvāsayāmāsa ca bhītam enam bhūtvā punaḥ saumya-vapuḥ mahātmā ||
verses.translation: Sañjaya said: Having thus spoken to Arjuna, Vasudeva showed His own gentle form again. The great-souled One, having assumed His pleasing form once more, consoled the frightened Arjuna.

word_breakdown.meaning: Sañjaya said
having thus spoken to Arjuna
Vasudeva — Krishna, Son of Vasudeva
His own form, His personal form
showed, revealed, manifested
again, once more
consoled, reassured, gave comfort to
this frightened one, him who was afraid
having become again, having assumed once more
of gentle / pleasing / beautiful form
the great-souled One, the Mahatma

commentary.dadaji: Sañjaya's narration is simple and luminous: the great-souled One assumed the gentle form and consoled the frightened one. Notice — it is Sañjaya who calls Krishna 'mahātmā,' the Great Soul. Even through the intermediary narrator, through the distance of reportage, the greatness of what has occurred cannot be contained. And 'saumya-vapuḥ' — the pleasing, gentle form — is not a diminishment of the cosmic. It is the Infinite choosing to be tender, choosing to console. Dear child, this is God's deepest nature: not the wielder of cosmic fire, but the Comforter of the frightened heart. Both are true. But it is the second that reaches us where we live.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Sañjaya's role in the Gita is often underappreciated. He is the witness-consciousness, the detached observer who reports without being swept away. The Upaniṣads speak of the 'sākṣī caitanya' — the witness awareness — and Sañjaya embodies this throughout. Significantly, he calls Krishna both 'Vāsudeva' (the son of Vasudeva, the personal deity) and 'mahātmā' (the Great Soul, pointing to the universal Ātman). This dual naming in a single verse reflects the same non-dual understanding Arjuna has just been brought to: the personal and the universal are one. 'Saumya-vapuḥ' — the gentle form — is the form of Brahman that is accessible to love.
commentary.yogananda: This transitional verse, narrated through Sañjaya's divine vision, captures the cosmic moment of divine condescension — God contracting from the Infinite to the personal, for love of a devotee. Yogananda often spoke of how the Infinite takes the finite form out of compassion, because the devotee's heart cannot yet hold the Boundless without the vessel cracking. 'Āśvāsayāmāsa' — 'consoled' — is one of the most beautiful words in the Gita. It means the Lord actively worked to restore Arjuna's peace, not passively waiting. This is the nature of the Divine Beloved: He does not stand apart in cosmic majesty; He stoops to dry our tears.
commentary.goyandka: Sañjaya's narration confirms the sequential manifestation: the Viśvarūpa (cosmic) is withdrawn, the four-armed Viṣṇu form appears briefly, and then finally the two-armed human form — described in the next verse — is assumed. The use of the periphrastic perfect tense 'darśayāmāsa' and 'āśvāsayāmāsa' (rather than simple past) indicates deliberate, completed actions, emphasizing the Lord's intentional and gracious condescension. The name 'Vāsudeva' carries the meaning 'one who dwells in all beings' (vāsayati iti vāsudevaḥ), reinforcing that even the gentle human form before Arjuna is the very Presence that pervades all existence.

verses.sanskrit: arjuna uvāca — dṛṣṭvedaṃ mānuṣaṃ rūpaṃ tava saumyaṃ janārdana | idānīm asmi saṃvṛttaḥ sa-cetāḥ prakṛtiṃ gataḥ ||
verses.transliteration: arjunaḥ uvāca — dṛṣṭvā idam mānuṣam rūpam tava saumyam janārdana | idānīm asmi saṃvṛttaḥ sa-cetāḥ prakṛtim gataḥ ||
verses.translation: Arjuna said: Seeing this Your gentle human form, O Janārdana, I am now composed — with my consciousness restored, returned to my own nature.

word_breakdown.meaning: Arjuna said
having seen this
the human form, the form of a man
Your gentle / pleasing (form)
O Janārdana — He who stirs / inspires mankind; Krishna
now, at this moment
I have become settled / composed / restored
with (my) consciousness (restored), in my right mind
returned to my own nature, restored to my natural state

commentary.dadaji: With these few words, Arjuna breathes again. 'I am restored. I am myself again.' How graciously the Lord manages our inner journey — He gives the vastness only as much as the vessel can hold, and then gently brings us back. The name 'Janārdana' is well-chosen here: it means 'One who stirs and inspires humanity.' The cosmic vision stirred Arjuna beyond his capacity; the gentle human form restores him to himself. Dear child, this is the rhythm of all deep spiritual experience: expansion and return, vastness and intimacy, the Infinite glimpsed and then the Beloved embraced. Both are real. Both are needed.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The phrase 'prakṛtim gataḥ' — 'returned to my own nature' — is philosophically interesting. What is Arjuna's 'own nature'? At the empirical level, it is his ordinary state of mind and body. But at the deeper level, the Gita's overall teaching is that our 'own nature' — svabhāva — is the Ātman itself, the Self that is pure consciousness. Arjuna has been temporarily displaced from his functional center by the overwhelming cosmic vision; now, with the gentle human form before him, he returns to equilibrium. The Chāndogya Upaniṣad uses the word 'samprasāda' — the state of being at ease, settled in oneself — for the condition of the realized soul. Arjuna is returning toward that state.
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna's statement 'sa-cetāḥ prakṛtim gataḥ' — 'with consciousness restored, returned to my nature' — describes the re-integration that must follow any overwhelming mystical experience. Yogananda spoke of how great samādhi experiences initially displace the ordinary personality and must gradually be integrated into daily consciousness. The soul must learn to hold both dimensions simultaneously — the cosmic and the personal — without being annihilated by either. Arjuna's restoration is not a retreat from the vision; it is the beginning of the long work of integrating what was seen into what is lived. The chapter does not end here; the teaching of bhakti that follows is precisely the path of that integration.
commentary.goyandka: This brief verse marks the end of the Viśvarūpa episode proper and the transition back to the primary teaching dialogue. 'Sa-cetāḥ' indicates that Arjuna's faculty of understanding and reasoning has been restored after the overwhelming experience. 'Prakṛtim gataḥ' — returned to his own nature — means that the violent inner disturbance caused by the cosmic vision has subsided and his mental equilibrium is reestablished. The epithet 'Janārdana' — one of Krishna's most common names in the Gita, meaning the One who drives away evil or who is sought by men — is appropriately used here as Arjuna returns to ordinary discourse with his divine Friend and Teacher.

verses.sanskrit: śrī-bhagavān uvāca — sudurdarśam idaṃ rūpaṃ dṛṣṭavān asi yan mama | devā apy asya rūpasya nityaṃ darśana-kāṅkṣiṇaḥ ||
verses.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca — su-durdarśam idam rūpam dṛṣṭavān asi yat mama | devāḥ api asya rūpasya nityam darśana-kāṅkṣiṇaḥ ||
verses.translation: The Blessed Lord said: This form of Mine which you have now seen is very difficult to behold. Even the gods ever yearn for a vision of this form.

word_breakdown.meaning: the Blessed Lord said
very difficult to behold, extremely hard to see
this form
you have seen, you beheld
which is Mine, which belongs to Me
even the gods, even the celestials
of this form
always, eternally, constantly
yearning for a vision / desirous of beholding

commentary.dadaji: Now the Lord speaks of the gentle human form — the very form Arjuna can see with his own eyes on the battlefield — and says that even the gods eternally yearn for a glimpse of it. Stop and let that astonish you, dear child. The four-armed Viṣṇu, the cosmic Infinite, the gentle human face of Krishna — all of these are 'su-durdarśam,' very difficult to see. The gods in their heavenly realms can imagine the Infinite, but they cannot have what Arjuna had: the Infinite walking beside them, talking, laughing, eating, sleeping in the same camp. The human birth is exalted beyond all celestial existence precisely because it allows this proximity.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse is a revolutionary statement: even the gods yearn for the vision that Arjuna has received. The Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad contains a fascinating episode where the gods approach Prajāpati for the knowledge of the Ātman, just as humans do. The gods are not omniscient — they are higher beings with greater powers but also with their own limitations and longings. The highest longing of even the celestials is the direct vision of Brahman in personal form. This elevates the bhakti relationship — the simple, loving, personal encounter with the Divine — above all the rituals and powers of the heavenly realms. Human devotion, when pure, surpasses all celestial achievement.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda taught that the Avatāra — the divine incarnation — is the supreme gift of God to humanity, a gift that even the angels do not receive in the same way. When God takes human form, it is specifically for the redemption and liberation of human souls, and it is precisely the human-accessible, approachable quality of the Avatar's form that makes it so precious. The gods can perceive the Infinite in their own mode, but they cannot sit beside the Infinite at a campfire, as Arjuna did. This is what they eternally long for — not the cosmic vision, but the intimate nearness of the Divine in human form, the gentle eyes of Krishna meeting theirs.
commentary.goyandka: Here the Lord clarifies which form is being referred to as 'su-durdarśam': it is the four-armed Viṣṇu form, distinct from both the cosmic Viśvarūpa and the two-armed human form. The Viṣṇu form, being the supreme divine personal manifestation, is even more difficult to obtain a vision of than the cosmic form, which can be intellectually apprehended through Vedic study. The fact that 'devāḥ api' — even the gods — are perpetually 'darśana-kāṅkṣiṇaḥ' (yearners for a vision) establishes a remarkable hierarchy: Arjuna's privilege exceeds that of Brahma, Indra, and all the celestials who eternally aspire to what Arjuna received by grace on the battlefield of Kurukṣetra.

verses.sanskrit: nāhaṃ vedair na tapasā na dānena na cejyayā | śakya evaṃ-vidho draṣṭuṃ dṛṣṭavān asi māṃ yathā ||
verses.transliteration: na aham vedaiḥ na tapasā na dānena na ca ijyayā | śakyaḥ evam-vidhaḥ draṣṭum dṛṣṭavān asi mām yathā ||
verses.translation: I cannot be seen in this manner — as you have just seen Me — through the Vedas, nor through austerity, nor through charity, nor through sacrifice.

commentary.dadaji: The Lord repeats this truth — you cannot see Me this way through Vedas, tapas, charity, or sacrifice — because it is so important that we fully absorb it. Why does He repeat it? Because the human mind, trained in the logic of effort and reward, keeps thinking: if I study harder, fast longer, give more, surely I can earn this. The Lord gently breaks this illusion: No. This is not the currency of that exchange. What opens the door to this vision is not achievement but love. Not performance but devotion. 'Bhaktyā tv ananyayā' — by undivided devotion alone — as the next verse will declare. Everything else prepares; only love arrives.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse, along with verse 48, forms a deliberate theological frame around the conclusion of Chapter 11: external religious means cannot produce the highest vision. The Māṇḍūkya Kārikā of Gauḍapāda argues that the Absolute cannot be reached by any path that assumes duality between the seeker and the sought. The Vedas, tapas, dāna, and yajña all presuppose a self that is separate from the Divine and must approach It through effort. But the Divine is not elsewhere — It is the very Self of the devotee. Therefore only the direct recognition of this identity, arising through grace and love, can produce the direct vision. This is why 'bhakti' in the next verse is not another technique but a fundamental transformation of relationship.
commentary.yogananda: The repetition of this teaching — that no external means can produce the highest vision — is the Gita's most radical and liberating statement. Yogananda often quoted this principle to his students who were exhausting themselves with techniques and disciplines, reminding them: 'The Divine is not to be conquered by your effort; It is to be wooed by your love.' The four means listed — Vedas, tapas, dāna, yajña — represent the four classical pathways of Hindu religious practice: jñāna (knowledge), tapas (austerity), karma (charity), and upāsanā (worship). All four, the Lord declares, fall short of the highest. What surpasses all four is the bhakti of the next verse — the total, exclusive, loving surrender of the self to the Self.
commentary.goyandka: This verse should be understood in conjunction with verses 48 and 54 as a triad forming the philosophical climax of Chapter 11. The four means listed here — Vedas, tapas, dāna, and ijyā (sacrifice/worship) — are a condensed version of the five listed in verse 48, all pointing to the same conclusion: no measure of external religious effort can by itself produce the direct vision of the Supreme Divine Form. The contrast between 'na śakyaḥ draṣṭum' (cannot be seen) in this verse and 'bhaktyā tv ananyayā śakyaḥ' (can be known through exclusive devotion) in the next creates a powerful teaching through negation and affirmation: all this cannot; this one thing can.

verses.sanskrit: bhaktyā tv ananyayā śakya aham evaṃ-vidho'rjuna | jñātuṃ draṣṭuṃ ca tattvena praveṣṭuṃ ca parantapa ||
verses.transliteration: bhaktyā tu ananyayā śakyaḥ aham evam-vidhaḥ arjuna | jñātum draṣṭum ca tattvena praveṣṭum ca parantapa ||
verses.translation: But through undivided, exclusive devotion — ananyā bhakti — O Arjuna, I can truly be known, and seen, and entered into, O Scorcher of Foes.

undivided, exclusive, without any other / without divided attention
I am able to be / I can be
in this very manner, as I truly am
O Arjuna

and to be seen — stage 2: direct vision
in truth, truly, in reality (tattva = truth/essence)
and to enter into, to merge — stage 3: union and merger
O Scorcher of Foes — epithet of Arjuna, one who burns enemies

commentary.dadaji: Here it is, dear child — the supreme gift of the entire eleventh chapter. After all the fire and thunder, after the cosmic vision and the terror and the prostrations, the Lord arrives at a single word: 'bhakti.' Not any kind of bhakti, but 'ananyā' — undivided, exclusive, without remainder. This is not the devotion that has room for other priorities, other loves, other pursuits. It is the heart given over completely. And then the Lord describes three stages that this devotion enables: jñātum (to know), draṣṭum (to see), praveṣṭum (to enter and become one with). Knowledge, Vision, Union — the complete arc of the soul's journey, all contained in the vessel of a single undivided love.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This is perhaps the most important verse in Chapter 11, and one of the most important in the entire Gita. The word 'tu' — 'but' — is the hinge of the entire passage. After listing everything that cannot produce the vision, the Lord introduces the one thing that can: 'bhaktyā tv ananyayā.' The Vedānta Sūtra asks 'janmādy asya yataḥ' — from what does this universe originate? The answer is Brahman. The Gita here answers a related question: through what does the individual jīva return to Brahman? Through ananyā bhakti. And the three infinitives — jñātum, draṣṭum, praveṣṭum — represent the three stages of Vedantic liberation: śravaṇa (hearing and knowing), manana (reflection and seeing), and nididhyāsana (deep meditation leading to merger).
commentary.yogananda: This verse is the crown jewel of the Gita's teaching on bhakti, and Yogananda returned to it again and again in his commentaries. 'Ananyā bhakti' — undivided devotion — is the state of the mind that has no other object of love, no competing attachment, no divided loyalty. It is the soul saying to God: 'You alone are my everything.' The three stages — jñātum (to know), draṣṭum (to see), praveṣṭum (to enter) — describe the progressive depth of God-realization. First comes knowing intellectually and intuitively that God is; then comes the direct vision of God; and finally comes the dissolution of the devotee into God — 'praveṣṭum' — entry and merger, the final union of the drop with the Ocean. This is the whole of the spiritual life in a single verse.
commentary.goyandka: This verse is the doctrinal heart of Chapter 11 and among the most cited verses in the entire Gita regarding the supremacy of bhakti. The word 'tu' (but) creates a deliberate and powerful contrast with the negations of the preceding two verses: all those means cannot; but this one can. 'Ananyayā' is a compound of 'an' (not) and 'anya' (other) — meaning devotion that has no other object, no admixture of desire for worldly or heavenly results. The three verbs — 'jñātum' (to know in truth), 'draṣṭum' (to see directly), 'praveṣṭum' (to enter and become one with) — represent three progressive levels of the devotee's relationship with the Supreme: cognitive recognition, perceptual vision, and ultimate ontological union. The word 'tattvena' (truly, in essence) modifies all three, indicating that these are not superficial or partial attainments but genuine realizations.

verses.sanskrit: mat-karma-kṛt mat-paramaḥ mad-bhaktaḥ saṅga-varjitaḥ | nirvairaḥ sarva-bhūteṣu yaḥ sa mām eti pāṇḍava ||
verses.transliteration: mat-karma-kṛt mat-paramaḥ mat-bhaktaḥ saṅga-varjitaḥ | nirvairaḥ sarva-bhūteṣu yaḥ saḥ mām eti pāṇḍava ||
verses.translation: He who acts for My sake, holds Me as the Supreme Goal, is devoted to Me, is free from attachment, and harbors no enmity toward any being — he comes to Me, O Pāṇḍava.

one for whom I am the Supreme Goal / highest value — quality 2
My devotee / one who is devoted to Me — quality 3
free from attachment, devoid of clinging — quality 4
without enmity / hostility toward anyone, free from hatred — quality 5
toward all beings, in relation to all creatures
whoever such a person is / he who is thus
comes to Me, reaches Me, attains Me
O Pāṇḍava — son of Pāṇḍu, epithet of Arjuna

commentary.dadaji: And here, dear child, is the portrait of the devotee — the one who comes to God. Not a portrait of a saint locked in a cave, but of a person fully engaged in life. Five qualities: doing God's work, holding God as the highest goal, loving God with devotion, releasing attachment, holding no enemy in the heart toward any being. Notice what is not on this list: no rigid rituals, no Vedic learning required, no caste or gender specified. Just these five inner orientations. And the promise is simple and absolute: 'sa mām eti' — he comes to Me. Not 'might come,' not 'if the conditions are right.' He comes to Me. This is the Lord's guarantee, the final word of the greatest chapter of the Gita.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The five qualities enumerated in this verse represent a complete system of spiritual transformation. 'Mat-karma-kṛt' transforms action from ego-centered to God-centered, corresponding to karma yoga. 'Mat-paramaḥ' transforms the goal from worldly to transcendent. 'Mad-bhaktaḥ' transforms the emotional life into a vehicle of devotion. 'Saṅga-varjitaḥ' — freedom from attachment — directly addresses the teaching of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad that 'āsakti' (attachment) is the bondage of the self. 'Nirvairaḥ sarva-bhūteṣu' — no enmity toward any being — is the experiential recognition of the Vedantic truth that the same Ātman dwells in all. Together, these five qualities describe the jīvanmukta: the one who is liberated while still living.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda considered this the golden verse that closes the great eleventh chapter with a practical map for the devotee. The five qualities form a complete inner yoga: work offered to God (karma yoga), God as the supreme aim (jñāna yoga), direct love of God (bhakti yoga), non-attachment (vairāgya), and universal non-enmity (sarvabhūtahita — goodwill toward all). Yogananda himself embodied all five throughout his life: he worked tirelessly for God's mission, held God as his only goal, loved the Divine with every fiber of his being, remained inwardly free from all personal attachment, and extended his love equally to all human beings without exception. This verse is not just a teaching — it is a life.
commentary.goyandka: This concluding verse of Chapter 11 is rightly considered its essential teaching and should be read as the practical complement to the lofty vision of verse 54. Verse 54 speaks of what ananyā bhakti can accomplish in terms of realization; verse 55 describes what ananyā bhakti looks like in terms of daily life and character. The five compound epithets — mat-karma-kṛt, mat-paramaḥ, mad-bhaktaḥ, saṅga-varjitaḥ, nirvairaḥ — are all present-tense descriptors, indicating ongoing dispositions rather than occasional practices. The promise 'sa mām eti' — 'he comes to Me' — is unconditional and unqualified. Śrī Śaṅkarācārya notes that 'eti' here means not merely proximity to the Divine but complete liberation and union. This is the siddha-lakṣaṇa, the mark of one who has attained perfection.
